revisions.rev:
The Pontifical and Royal [[University of Santo Tomas]] celebrated its 400th anniversary in 2011. The agenda ahead of the University's quadricentennary in 2011 includes the introduction of new academic programs, improvements in the University's infrastructure, and other projects to raise USTâs national and international prominence and promote its role as a social catalyst.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/supplement/rectors_supplement/memos_to_the_quadricentennial_rector Memos to the Quadricentennial Rector], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
Plans to open satellite campuses in [[Santa Rosa, Laguna]] and another in [[General Santos City]] are being put in place.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/europe_firm_may_finance_general_santos_campus Europe firm may finance General Santos campus], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
Physical developments for the Sampaloc campus are ongoing. The Plaza Mayor in front the [[Main Building (University of Santo Tomas)|Main Building]], together with the Quadricentennial Square which will feature the Tetraglobal sculpture, the Quadricentennial Fountain, and the Quadricentennial Alumni Walkway were constructed in 2006.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/special_reports/synchronized_constructions_in_ust Synchronized constructions in UST], retrieved 27 December 2009</ref> To accommodate the needs of extra space for the growing number of student activities, the UST Tan Yan Kee Student Center was built in front of the [[University of Santo Tomas Miguel de Benavides Library|Miguel de Benavides Library]]. The more than 80-year old Main Building, and the artifacts and art works in the [[UST Museum of Arts and Sciences]] were recently placed under the preservation of the UST Heritage Conservation program in December 2008.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/circle/preserving_heritage_on_a_high_note Preserving heritage on a high note], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
The UST Benavides Cancer Institute, part of the five-year redevelopment plan and expansion of the [[University of Santo Tomas Hospital|UST Hospital]] for its 60-year celebration and the quadricentennial celebration, was also established in the year 2006.<ref>[http://www.usthospital.com.ph/bci/bci.php A Higher Level of Caring], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
Part of the University's infrastructure modernization is the construction of an P800-million, four-storey gymnasium capable of seating 5,792, designed by Thomasian architects JosÃ© Pedro Recio and Carmelo T. Casas. The construction is now in full swing after university officials, led by Rector Rolando V. de la Rosa, O.P., led its groundbreaking ceremonies last August 2008.<ref>[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php?Itemid=104&id=639&option=com_content&task=view UST Starts New Gymnasium Construction Due at 400th Anniversary], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
The [[University of Santo Tomas Publishing House|UST Publishing House]] in 2001 launched its quadricentennial project, â400 Books at 400!â, publishing books in a range of disciplines, from theology to literature to medicine, written in both Filipino and English. The Publishing house is more than half way in completing this objective.<ref>[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php/news/university/409-ust-publishing-house-launches-book-titles-for-2007.html UST Publishing House Launches Book Titles for 2007], retrieved 27 December 2009.</ref>
== Quadricentennial Commission == A '''Quadricentennial Commission''' was formed to formulate preparations for the celebration of UST Quadricentennial Jubilee. The commission is headed by the UST Rector, Rev. Fr. Rolando V. de la Rosa, O.P., as chairman. The following are its members:<ref name="UST Gears for 2011">[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php/2011.html UST Gears for 2011], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref> * Chairman ''(Rector)'' * Vice Chairman ''(Vice Rector)'' * Secretary ''(Assistant to the Rector for Administration)'' * Committees *# Quadricentennial Committee ''(Assistant to the Rector for Grants and Endowment)'' *# Major Infrastructure Projects Committee ''(Facilities Management Office Director'') *# External Relations Committee ''(Office of the Alumni Affairs'') *# Grand Celebrations Committee ''(Secretary General'') *# Documentation and Publication Committee ''(Office for Public Affairs / Executive Secretary of the Rector)'' *# Media and Publicity Committee ''(Office for Public Affairs / EdTech)''
== Symbolization == [[File:UST Quadricentennial Logo ALT.png|thumbnail|200px|right|The Tongues of Fire, the official Quadricentennial logo]] === Quadricentennial Logo === The Tongues of Fire is the official logo for the Quadricentennial celebration of the university. This logo features the outline of the UST Main Building Tower as a concrete symbol of the stability, integrity and 400 years of existence of the university. From the cross of the Main Building emanate four tongues of fire that spell out U, S, and T. The tongues of fire reference the future of the university, some ideals, and are reminiscent of the stripes of the Tiger, the school's mascot. The Quadricentennial logo was designed by Dopy Doplon, a Thomasian.<ref name="QLogo">[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=439&Itemid=104 Tongues of Fire]. retrieved December 26, 2009</ref>
=== Quadricentennial Song === The '''Ako'y Isang Tomasino''' composed by UST [[University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Engineering|Faculty of Engineering]] alumnus Gerry de Leon, is the official theme song of the Quadricentennial celebration. It bested four other finalists in the Q Songwriting Contest Grand Finals held last Dec. 10 at the Albertus Magnus Auditorium. It was performed by Sam Velarde, a long time friend of Gerry de Leon, and a [[Philippine School of Business Administration|PSBA]]-Manila alumnus. The song was launched during the â400 days to 400 years Countdownâ on Dec. 18 at the UST Football Field.<ref>[http://www.tribune.net.ph/metro/20091215met5.html UST picks official Quadricentennial hymn] ''[[The Daily Tribune]]''. Published December 15, 2009</ref>
=== Quadricentennial Prayer === The Quadricentennial prayer was unveiled to the public during the â400 days to 400 years Countdownâ on Dec. 18. It was recited by Fr. Pompeyo de Mesa, O.P. with a candle-lighting ceremony.<ref name="Paskuhan2009">[http://www.varsitarian.net/breaking_news/20091219/paskuhan_draws_crowd_of_50000 Paskuhan draws crowd of 50,000]. retrieved December 26, 2009</ref>
=== Quadricentennial Flag === The Quadricentennial flag consists of two horizontal stripes of equal width, the upper one gold and the lower one white. The two colors are defined as [[school colors]] of the University because of its [[Pontifical university|Pontifical]] status. Embroidered with '''2011''', the flag features the sun and the colors ''yellow'' and ''blue'' taken from the logo of the University.<ref name="Paskuhan2009"/>
=== Quadricentennial Countdown Clock === The countdown clock, which is a '''Swatch Beatman''', is produced by a Swiss watch company [[Swatch]]. It is designed by the former [[The Varsitarian|Varsitarian]] art director Jonathan Gamalinda.<ref name="Paskuhan2009"/>
=== Quadricentennial Mascot === The mascot is named QUSTER which stands for '''Q'''uadricentennial '''U'''niversity of '''S'''anto '''T'''omas Tig'''er'''.
== Infrastructure == [[Image:UST Fountain.jpg|right|thumb|250px|UST Quadricentennial Fountain]]
=== University Marker === A one-foot-by-three-feet marble marker in Plaza Intramuros near the main vehicular entrance of the campus was unveiled on February 4, 2010.
It was designed by Archt. John Joseph T. Fernandez, Dean of the [[University of Santo Tomas College of Architecture|College of Architecture]] and Archt. Froilan M. Fontecha, faculty member of the same college. It bears the name of the university, its seal on the left, and the year 1611 on the right.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20100218/alumni_center_ust_marker_simbahayan_launched Alumni Center, UST marker, 'Simbahayan' launched], retrieved 25 January 2011</ref>
=== Quadricentennial Square=== Replacing the old Colayco Park and its adjacent UST Cooperative Center, the Quadricentennial Square was built as a memorial of the University's four centuries of existence. It has two main features: the ''Quadricentennial Fountain'' and the ''Quattromondial''. It is located between the Main Building and the Miguel de Benavides Library. '''The Colayco Shrine''', an iron statue commemorating the World War 2 victim ''Capt. Manuel Colayco'', was nowhere to be found since its removal from the site in 2006.
==== ''Quadricentennial Fountain'' ==== It is a recreational water attraction and interactive fountain was unveiled on 2007.
It was designed and built by Industron Inc., the same designer of [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] and Liwasang Bonifacio fountains in Manila.<ref name="Unraveling UST fountain spectacle">[http://www.varsitarian.net/sci_tech/unraveling_ust_fountain_spectacle Unraveling UST fountain spectacle], retrieved 29 December 2009</ref>
The fountain has sun-like floor patterns to pay tribute to the Universityâs patron saint, Thomas Aquinas. It also has four cornerstones that highlight UST milestones during its first, second, third, and fourth centuries of existence.<ref name="Unraveling UST fountain spectacle"/>
According to UST Facilities Management Office administrator Antonio Espejo, the fountain uses recycled water treated with chlorine. It runs three times a day (6AM to 8AM, 11AM to 1PM, and 5PM to 8PM).<ref name="Unraveling UST fountain spectacle"/>
==== ''Quattromondial'' ==== An artwork and piece of structure was unveiled for the Quadricentennial celebrations last January 27, 2011.<ref name="Archt Orlina">[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php/2011/744-archt-orlina-signs-accord-to-build-tetraglobal-sculpture.html Archt. Orlina Signs Accord to Build Tetraglobal Sculpture], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
The '''Quattromondial''' is a monument built made of bronze and glass. It is a ten-meter-high structure made by artist '''Ramon Orlina''', a UST alumnus.<ref name="Countdown to 2011 begins">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20091216/countdown_to_2011_begins Countdown to 2011 begins], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
The monument features four figures representing the young Filipino student, the young Filipina student, the Thomasian teacher, and the Dominican monk-scholar. These were modeled by actor '''Piolo Pascual''' (''Filipino student''), Orlinaâs daughter '''Monina''' (''Filipina student''), beauty queen '''Charlene Gonzales''' (''Thomasian teacher''), and '''Fr. Rolando V. dela Rosa, O.P.''' (''Dominican friar'').<ref name="Olazo/Orlina: Of light and delight">[http://www.varsitarian.net/circle/20101130/olazoorlina_of_light_and_delight Olazo/Orlina: Of light and delight], retrieved 25 January 2011</ref><ref name="Quattromondial">[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20110123-316039/Quattromondial-UST-embraces-birthright-destiny âQuattromondialâ: UST embraces birthright, destiny], retrieved 24 January 2011</ref> Upon the four near-naked figures, whose genitals are covered by a long strip of ribbon, rests a globe; and like the earth, it tilts 23.5 degrees.
According to Orlina, the four figures represent the four centuries of '''''excellence''''' (Filipino student), '''''erudition''''' (Thomasian teacher), '''''spirituality''''' (Dominican monk) and '''''tradition''''' (Filipina student) that the University has displayed and inspired in every one of its stakeholders. The globe represents globalization, with all its benefits and hindrances, such as environmental degradation and cultural divisions.
The ribbon with an inscription in Latin signifying accomplishment, scholarliness and wisdom streams out of the globe.<ref name="Quattromondial"></ref> It reads: {{cquote|''Pontificia et Regalis Universitas Sancti Thomae Aquantis Manilana MDCXI. Contemplari et Contemplata aliis Tradere. In Veritate fideles. In Labore proficientes. In Caritate divites.''}}
===UST Gymnasium and Sports Complex=== {{main|University of Santo Tomas Sports Complex}}
Replacing the original UST Gymnasium and the old Engineering Sports Complex, the construction of the 800-million-peso UST Sports Complex began after the Vatican gave its "blessing" to the project.<ref name="Vatican OKs sports complex"/> It is set to be inaugurated on August 15, 2011.<ref>[http://www.varsitarian.net/breaking_news/20110121/ust_set_to_open_quadricentennial_week UST set to open Quadricentennial Week], retrieved 25 January 2011.</ref>
It was designed by Thomasian architects Jose Pedro Recio and Carmelo Rosas. It will stand on what used to be the Engineering Sports Complex, basketball courts, and the adjacent football field. It will house training areas for gymnastics, aerobics, taekwondo, judo, table tennis, fencing, and badminton at its ground floor. Some features include a ticket counter, a museum, a dance hall for the [[Salinggawi Dance Troupe]], and a fitness room. Its main attraction is a basketball court surrounded by bleachers rising up to the fourth level.<ref name="Vatican OKs sports complex">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20090715/vatican_oks_sports_complex Vatican OKs sports complex], retrieved 29 December 2009</ref>
=== Thomasian Alumni Center === {{main|Thomasian Alumni Center}} To be built on the site of the original UST Gymnasium, the alumni center will be used as a venue for alumni gatherings, various university events, and lodging services for visitors. It is according to the pursuit of the university's Office for Alumni Relations to build a center to cater the needs in catering the growing number of UST Alumni. The existing Olympic-sized swimming pool located nearby would be kept and refurbished.<ref name="Four-story alumni center soon to rise"/> It is projected to be completed and opened in 2012.<ref name="UST set to open Quadricentennial Week">[http://www.varsitarian.net/breaking_news/20110121/ust_set_to_open_quadricentennial_week UST set to open Quadricentennial Week], retrieved January 29, 2011.</ref>
The design was chosen from seven winners in a competition among students organized by the College of Architecture. Abelardo Tolentino Jr., an outstanding Thomasian alumni for Architecture, worked on the design to produce the final blueprint.<ref name="Four-story alumni center soon to rise">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20090715/four_story_alumni_center_soon_to_rise, Four-story alumni center soon to rise], Retrieved 29 December 2009</ref>
US-based Thomasian medical practitioners raised and donated USD 1 million to assist the construction of the alumni center.<ref name="UST set to open Quadricentennial Week"></ref>
=== University Sites as National Cultural Treasures ===
Four structures within the University campus were declared National Cultural Treasures by the National Museum. The declaration was made on 25 January 2010. The following sites were: *The Main Building ''(the first earthquake-resistant building in the Philippines)'' *Arch of the Centuries ''(the remnant of UST's original building from Intramuros)'' *Central Seminary ''(the home of the oldest college of Ecclesiastical Studies in the Philippines)'' *The Grandstand and Parade Grounds ''(the venue where a mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II was held)''
'''The Cultural Properties Preservation and Protection Act''' describes ''National Cultural Treasures'' as unique objects found in the Philippines that possess outstanding historical, cultural, artistic, and/or scientific value. These are considered as significant and important to the Philippines.<ref name="NationalTreasures">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20100127/ust_sites_declared_national_treasures UST sites declared 'National Treasures'], retrieved 25 January 2011.</ref>
== Pre-2011 Events == === 4 horas, 4 dias, 4 hundred days, 400 taon === The Quadricentennial countdown to 2011 coincided with UST's Christmas tradition Paskuhan held on December 18, 2009. The theme was called as such because the party lasted for 4 hours on December 18, which is 4 days before December 22, which is 400 days before January 28, 2011, which is the Grand Opening of UST's Quadricentennial Celebrations.<ref name="UST to launch 400-day countdown">[http://www.gmanews.tv/print/179634 UST to launch 400-day countdown for Quadricentennial on Friday], retrieved 31 December 2009</ref> The official kick-off and launching of the countdown was intended to be held on December 22 but the university was expected to be already on its Christmas vacation during that day.
January 28 is the feast day of St. [[Thomas Aquinas]], the patron saint of the university and from where it was named after. UST was founded on April 28, 1611.
The Paskuhan festivities and the Quadricentennial Countdown were hosted by UST alumni - beauty queen [[Miriam Quiambao]] and TV personality [[Kim Atienza]].
=== Simbahayan 400 === '''Simbahayan 400:''' "Tomasino para sa Simbahan at Bayan" or Thomasians for the Church and the Country is a socio-civic activity that would start on January 2010.<ref name="Countdown to 2011 begins"/> The Quadricentennial's "centerpiece project", according to the Rector Rev. Fr. Rolando De La Rosa, O.P., aims for UST to adopt some 400 villages with the help of non-governmental organization [[Gawad Kalinga]].<ref name="Countdown to 2011 begins"/><ref name="400 days to 400 years">[http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20091217-242596/400-days-to-400-years 400 Days to 400 Years], retrieved 26 December 2009</ref>
=== Thomasian Global Trade Expo === The three-day event will be led by Thomasian tycoons such as Jollibee Foods Corp. president Tony Caktiong, and Mercury Drug president Vivian Que-Ascona in July 2010.
It is a three-day exposition of businesses owned and/or managed by Thomasian students or alumni. It was held at SMX Convention Center in [[Mall of Asia]] Complex in Pasay City. Started on October 15, 2010, the expo featured a job fair; shopping bazaars; wellness festival; arts, design, and construction booths; celebrity shows; food and beverage stalls; entrepreneur workshops; and advocacy seminars.<ref name="Thomasian Expo set at SMX">http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleid=621098, Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> [[Jollibee]] Foods Corp.âs '''Tony Caktiong''', Mercury Drugâs '''Viviene Que-Ascona''', and '''Joel Cruz''' of Aficionado were among the Thomasian businessmen who joined.<ref name="Thomasian Global Expo set">http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20101001/thomasian_global_expo_set, Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref>
The expo is a joint project of UST Alumni Association, UST Office for Alumni Affairs, and the UST Thomasian Alumni Leaders Association.
Some of the proceeds of this event will fund the building of the Thomasian Alumni Center.<ref name="Thomasian Expo set at SMX"></ref><ref name="Thomasian Global Expo set"></ref>
=== Lumina Pandit === UST's rare book collections and historic documents will shown to the public through an exhibition in Miguel de Benavides Library.<ref name="Countdown to 2011 begins"/> '''Lumina Pandit''' is a Latin phrase that means ''spreading the light.'' The exhibit will showcase "Doctrina Christiana," the first book published in the Philippines.<ref name="400 days to 400 years"/> Other books and documents that will be shown include a rare copy of Copernicus' book and academic records of UST alumni such as those of national heroes [[JosÃ© Rizal]] and [[Apolinario Mabini]];<ref name="Countdown to 2011 begins"/> four Philippine presidents; six Supreme Court chief justices; and other significant alumni.<ref name="400 days to 400 years"/>
=== Grand Living Rosary === {{Empty section|date=January 2011}}
== Quadricentennial Week == The highlight of the Quadricentennial celebrations were opened with the Opening of the Jubilee Door and a Mass held on January 24, 2011. === Opening of Jubilee Door === {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
=== Q Parade === {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
=== Cheermania XVI === The annual competition was held on January 26, 2010. The University also invited other school's dance companies to compete with each other featuring different Philippine Festivals.
The Cheermania was won by College of Commerce Cheering Squad and the Philippine Festivals Inivational Competition is won by FEU Dance Company.
=== Unveiling of the Quattromondial === {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
=== Grand Q Program and Countdown === {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
=== Grand Alumni Night and Gala === {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
== 2011 Events == {{Empty section|date=May 2011}}
== International recognition ==
=== Holy See's recognition === UST being a pontifical university, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] was invited but cannot grace the occasions by being physically present in the University. Instead, a special envoy would be sent for the celebrations.<ref>[http://www.gmanews.tv/story/190941/pope-not-coming-to-rp-for-ust-quadricentennial-anniversary Pope not coming to RP for UST quadricentennial anniversary]. Retrieved 18 May 2010</ref>
Nevertheless, the pope declared a Jubilee year form January 2011 until January 2012 coinciding the University's quadricentennary. Although not physically present in UST, the holy father will deliver a recorded video on January 28, feast day of St. Thomas Aquinas. On this day, a thanksgiving mass will be held. No UST officials were sent to Vatican City as the Vatican Press Office volunteered to record the said papal greeting.<ref name="Vatican declares Jubilee Year">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/20110126/vatican_declares_jubilee_year Vatican declares Jubilee Year], retrieved 27 January 2011.</ref>
In December 2010, the [[Roman Catholic Church]]'s [[Apostolic Penitentiary]] allowed in a decree Archbishop Gaudencio Cardinal Rosales to bestow a [[Blessing (Roman Catholic Church)|Papal Blessing]] carrying a [[Indulgence|Plenary Indulgence]] in the Jubilee Mass held on January 24, 2011.<ref name="Vatican declares Jubilee Year"></ref>
Upon the request of Rector Magnificus Fr. Rolando dela Rosa, O.P., a separate decree granted plenary indulgence to ''âall those who piously join the sacred rites, ceremonies, and activities in celebration of the Jubilee at the University of Santo Tomasâ''.
=== Visit of Spain's Royal Crown === The King of Spain [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] has also been invited.<ref name="400 days to 400 years"/>
=== UNESCO Exhibit === {{Empty section|date=January 2011}}

== Commemoration and memorabilias == [[Image:UST 200-Peso PostageStamps.jpg|right|250px|thumb|A 200-peso bill with the UST Quadricentennial Logo and Philippine Postage Stamps featuring UST landmarks and symbols]]
=== Commemorative bills and medals === Unveiled before the press conference held on January 21, 2011, [[Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas]] (BSP) will issue commemorative [[Philippine two hundred peso bill|200-peso bills]] with the UST Quadricentennial logo overprinted on it. BSP is set to release two-billion-peso worth of these 200-peso bills - in general circulation and legal tender. In addition, the central bank will also release 400 copies of uncut two-piece 200-peso bills (amounting to [[Philippine peso|PhP]] 400.00).
Aside from the peso notes, BSP will issue commemorative gold and silver medals featuring the image of Msgr. Miguel de Benavides, O.P., the University's founder.
=== Commemorative stamps === Named ''Unending Grace'' stamps<ref name="Philpost to issue 'UST 400 years' stamps on Jan. 25">[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/01/21/11/philpost-issue-ust-400-years-stamps-jan-25 Philpost to issue 'UST 400 years' stamps on Jan. 25], retrieved 26 January 2011</ref>, Philippine Postal Corp. issues four commemorative stamps with 7-peso denomination. The designs featured were: * UST Main Building * Central Seminary * Arch of the Centuries * ''The Foundation of the University of Santo Tomas'' painting
The PhilPost will produce 100,000 pieces of these stamps. 10,200 copies of souvenir sheets worth Php 37.00 each will also the issued.
=== 2011 Thomasian Planner === {{Empty section|date=January 2011}}
=== UST Quadricentennial Watch by Swatch === The Swiss company, [[Swatch]], produces four different designer watches to commemorate the University's 400th jubilee year. The watches were named: * The Thomasian * Dominican Duo - White * Dominican Duo - Black * Quadricentennial Swatch
